content.body: i have a page that i wrote in HTML5 forms, then wrote a javascript implementation of the validity API
the latest builds of WebKit are breaking my page, and i'm trying to figure out if they or i implemented wrong
when i hit submit, the page jumps to the first empty form element
before calling onsubmit
any hints as to what i should look into?
i haven't played with HTML5 forms in a long whule
Forms *should* validate before submitting, and not submit if anything's invalid.
til: do you have the required attribute set on those empty inputs?
miketaylr: nope
i've found a couple bugs in earlier chrome builds.  one was a bug in their implementation of checkValidity
the other was a disagreement between Hixie and myself on what it means for a checkbox group to be @required
but this has otherwise worked great until now
TabAtkins_: i don't disagree, but i have to figure out if the rejected form should be considered invalid or not
right now, i'm using form.@onsubmit="return checkSurveyValidity();" to validate the form and block it from submitting on pre-HTML5 browsers
i may need to use a different event handler.  webkit isn't running my validator at all (which means my smooth scrolling and message-displaying script isn't running)
AryehGregor, I think Asa Dotzler has a bunch of statistics on how much of various types of Mozilla contributions are employees vs. volunteers
reads the W3C process document and learns that PER status is basically PR + LC at the same time
didn't realize it had so many aspects of Last Call
looks up, then goes to bed
jgraham: Nor did I. Until recetnly, you only had to wait two hours, worse case, AFAIK
var x = new XMLHttpRequest;
you learn something new every day
i wouldn't omit those invocation parens though
it's a function call... don't make it look like something else
Is it possible to get two separate contexts ctx1 and ctx2 that refer to the same canvas? I would like to use ctx1.lineTo(x,y) and ctx2.lineTo(x,y) to draw two curves in parallel.
I can probably hack a solution together myself, but I would like html5 to solve the problem for me :)
what do you mean with "draw in parallel"?
you draw stuff to the canvas... and once you're done with that and the UI is back in control... the updated drawing is shown
drawing onto one context or thousands doesn't change anything
pokes nielsle

I am toying with a canvas based multi user paint program. Whenever the user move the mouse I use lineTo(x,y) to draw a line. If another user draws something then the client recieves a json object and I also use lineTo to draw that. This works nicely unless the client revieves a json object while the user is in the process of drawing a stroke. I can probably solve this by creating some locks.
Reading http://www.w3.org/mid/4C1359A1.7050403⊙in I'm not really sure what to say... I did not quite agree with the removal of the Atom mapping, but going as far as objecting goes way too far.
It seems e.g. Julian is far less constrained in that regard going as far as raising an issue over something as simple as a reference.
Does that mean the progress is tilted in the advantage of people that like to bicker over every detail?
nielsle, well... you just have to update your canvas if an event occurs (input, network, whatever)
that's all there is to it
(it's single threaded - there are no locks)
he means a lock to indicate it cannot be updated right this instant because something else is going on
nielsle, we might get dedicated path objects in the future, but not for now
pretty good read: http://bitworking.org/news/2010/06/distributed-extensibility
annevk: Yes you are right. I was asking for a path object. (Sorry if I was unclear).
I believe the thinking is that it should have been that way from the beginning, but in the beginning everything went fast, and so we're stuck with some not too great design decisions
but we can also still paper over them in the future, and had we not it would probably have taken all much longer to get universally deployed
Ah I see. Thank you for the answers.
what is http://wiki.whatwg.org/index.php?title=Talk:Timed_tracks&curid=1928&diff=4923&oldid=4716 about?
ah
it seems to be about http://wiki.whatwg.org/index.php?title=Timed_tracks&action=historysubmit&diff=4647&oldid=4645

I like fixing bugs and then finding out other code relies upon those bugs.
